awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Large Scale Simulations Enabled Materials Engineering for Heterogeneous Ice Nucleation
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Sarupria, Sapna 
Proposal Number: 1653352 
Institution: Clemson University 
Title: CAREER: Large Scale Simulations Enabled Materials Engineering for Heterogeneous Ice Nucleation 

Understanding and controlling ice nucleation is an important problem with numerous potential applications in the food, transportation, and energy generation industries. The goal of this proposal is to develop an integrated approach combining molecular simulations and data analysis to enable the high-throughput screening of materials that modulate ice nucleation. The project will focus on two systems, one involving ice nucleation on self-assembled monolayers, and the second ice-nucleating proteins. The proposed approach is based on the hypothesis that there are characteristic signatures of a material's ice nucleating propensity within the interfacial water properties. The project aims to identify those signatures and formulate molecular descriptors that accelerate ice nucleation. The goal of the proposed education plan is to use an integrated approach to improve the understanding of the multidisciplinary field of computational materials science by graduate and undergraduate students. The proposed activities include a hackathon formulated in the context of computational materials science simulation challenges and a molLego touch-screen game (similar to Lego) aimed at constructing nanoscale materials in a visual learning environment.

The proposed research plan aims to understand the thermodynamics and kinetics of ice nucleation near self-assembled monolayers and ice-nucleating proteins. Computational tools developed in the PI?s group speed up sampling of nucleation events by more than a factor of 20 compared to traditional Molecular Dynamics simulations, thereby enabling studies of ice nucleation near surfaces. The plan is to analyze the extensive dataset of nucleation events, free energy landscapes, and interfacial water properties to identify the key signatures that indicate the ice-nucleating propensity of a surface. Based on knowledge of the key signatures, high-throughput screening of the surface nucleating propensity will be performed using membrane-based surfaces. The proposed research will potentially lead to computationally efficient cost-effective techniques for screening materials for ice nucleation propensity.

por.por_cntn:
Heterogeneous nucleation – nucleation in the presence of a foreign particle – is the primary pathway for ice nucleation in nature. It enables crystallization, by the birth of an ice embryo, in conditions not otherwise possible. Heterogeneous ice nucleation has tremendous impacts in a wide range of fields such as energy generation and storage, agriculture, food industry, climate science, cryopreservation of cells, tissues and organs, and transportation. There currently exist no design principles in terms of molecular descriptors to engineer new materials that control ice nucleation. Understanding the underlying molecular behavior and developing such design principles remains a grand challenge in this field. Studies of ice nucleation are challenging because of the difficulty in accessing the relevant length and timescales in both experiments and computer simulations. With increasing computational power, we are only now starting to reach the timescales necessary to observe heterogeneous ice nucleation in traditional molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. However, these studies are still limited to cases with huge driving forces (such as large supercooling), model surfaces, or very potent ice nucleating agents (e.g., silver iodide).

 

In our research, we focused on studying heterogeneous ice nucleation on a broad range of surfaces using MD simulations. To enable this scale of studies, we developed a novel method called Rigid Seeding that allows us to characterize the nucleation rates of and preferred structure formed during heterogeneous ice nucleation. The method is computationally less expensive than most existing approaches and enables us to study ice nucleation in broad driving force conditions. We span a range of 100s of orders of magnitude in nucleation rate of 100s using this approach. Using this method, we have studied ice nucleation on a wide range of self-assembled monolayers with varying chemistries and lattice structure. We find that the nucleation rate is most sensitive to the chemistry and is mildly affected by the lattice structure. These observations can be related partially to changes in the interfacial water structure. The work enables us to identify molecular parameters that can guide the design of materials for modulating ice nucleation.

 


Last Modified: 06/21/2024
Modified by: Sapna Sarupria

Image
  • Developing novel molecular dynamics methods to study heterogeneous ice nucleation to enable molecular-level strategies to guide the design of materials that modulate ice nucleation.
    Sapna Sarupria
    Copyrighted
    Sapna Sarupria
    Heterogeneous Ice Nucleation
por.por_txt_cntn:
Heterogeneous nucleation  nucleation in the presence of a foreign particle  is the primary pathway for ice nucleation in nature. It enables crystallization, by the birth of an ice embryo, in conditions not otherwise possible. Heterogeneous ice nucleation has tremendous impacts in a wide range of fields such as energy generation and storage, agriculture, food industry, climate science, cryopreservation of cells, tissues and organs, and transportation. There currently exist no design principles in terms of molecular descriptors to engineer new materials that control ice nucleation. Understanding the underlying molecular behavior and developing such design principles remains a grand challenge in this field. Studies of ice nucleation are challenging because of the difficulty in accessing the relevant length and timescales in both experiments and computer simulations. With increasing computational power, we are only now starting to reach the timescales necessary to observe heterogeneous ice nucleation in traditional molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. However, these studies are still limited to cases with huge driving forces (such as large supercooling), model surfaces, or very potent ice nucleating agents (e.g., silver iodide).

These observations can be related partially to changes in the interfacial water structure. The work enables us to identify molecular parameters that can guide the design of materials for modulating ice nucleation.
